claims_to_validate.claim_text: The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.

The daily wage calculator in payroll settings overrides the formula configured in leave policy for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is intentionally superseded by payroll settings. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly calculated based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll deduction discrepancies.

The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator does not correctly account for leap years. When calculating gratuity for an employee with service spanning 2024 (a leap year), the system counts 365 days instead of 366 days, resulting in an incorrect total service period (607 days instead of 608 days) and an incorrect gratuity amount (AED 10,476.98 instead of AED 10,494.24).

Daily wage calculation for pro-rated amounts is consistently producing slightly lower amounts due to decimal precision errors. The formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but results show amounts less by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals across all employee calculations.
System gratuity calculation showed slight difference from manual calculation (Bayzat: AED 231,821.10, Manual: AED 252,485)
The system's gratuity calculation may not transparently handle February 29th in leap years, causing slight discrepancies in total service days calculation (912 vs 913 days).
The system uses a complex calculation methodology for gratuity that differs from manual expectations, specifically in handling partial years above 5 years of service and leap year day counting.
System calculates 623 days instead of 622 days when computing job tenure, potentially causing slight variations in gratuity calculations.
Platform uses a hardcoded daily wage calculation of (Basic Salary / 30), which differs from client's preferred method of (Basic × 12 / 365)

System calculates leave salary based on a fixed daily rate configuration in policy, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days and prorated calculations. The specific case involved dividing daily wage by 30 days instead of 31 days, resulting in a slight salary amount difference.

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., on Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., on Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes misaligned between the Time Off and Payroll modules. This causes incorrect salary deduction amounts due to a timing mismatch in working days calculation.

The system calculates unpaid leave deductions using a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can result in deduction amounts that don't precisely match the expected monthly salary.

The platform currently displays incorrect remarks for daily wage calculations in February, showing 31 days instead of the actual 29 days for leap years. While the backend calculation remains accurate, the frontend display creates potential user confusion.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual policy-level leave calculation settings. Unpaid leave deductions are calculated using a system-wide daily rate instead of policy-specific methods, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not match the month when leave occurred.
Salary is based on a standard 26 working days per month, calculated from 365 annual days minus 52 weekly offs, resulting in 313 working days divided by 12 months.
For unpaid leave, the daily wage calculator configured in payroll settings takes precedence over the leave policy formula. The leave policy formula is greyed out and cannot be applied.
Unpaid leave deductions depend on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.
The system defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize 366 days in leap years when calculating total service period for gratuity computations.
The daily wage calculation (basic + allowances / 30) produces systematically slightly lower pro-rated amounts by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.
Leave days are accrued only at end of month, not prorated for partial months
Unclear rules about whether the departure date is counted as a working day, leading to potential variations in service duration calculation.
System calculates partial years using specific day-counting logic, including leap year adjustments (using 366 as divisor when applicable)
The system cannot retroactively adjust daily wage calculations when public holidays are added after initial payroll processing.
Leave salary calculation is rigidly tied to predefined policy configurations, which cannot be easily overridden for specific scenarios
